column38: I can only partly decipher this letter which is on behalf of Lady Spelman whose late husband's estate is threatened with sequestration by the committee of sequestration in Norfolk. It is a rather long letter.

column48: Hand: K; Place of origin: Catholic; Destination: Reformed

column38: Some years since he came to the Parsonage of Jamaica and was allowed by the Bishop to retain the small living of Swafham. Bulbeck in England. He has now married a wealthy widow and resigned his vicaridge to one who needs it more, and writes to the Bishop and leaves it in his hands as to what he ought to do as to the English living.

He asks her to pardon his incivility, but he is about to set off
on a voyage and her son Philip refuses to pay him his debt of
6 pounds ten shillings.

column38:
Critical reflections on the achievements at the synod and an eloquent declaration of the principles that actuate his faith and thinking.

[There are words I cannot decipher].

column48: Place of origin: Catholic, Reformed, Lutheran

column38: Bearing high testimony to the valuable support given by the county and the Earl of Carbury, e.g., in providing free quarters and raising a complete troop of horse, and undertaking to provide 600 recruits for his army and £600 monthly for its maintenance.

The Irishman has finished the Irish M.S. and he will send on the translation. Saw Mr. Bagford who has not yet been able to obtain a mill, but will send Lhuyd the magnifying glass and a parcel of rare stones and a list of writers as have treated of Wales. Mr. Stonestreet will get the Flint done by Friday and send it with other things. Mr. Wanley is coming to Oxford will bring a very ancient Welsh book with him for Lhuyd to see. The ship carrying Lhuyd's letter to Maryland has not yet sailed.

Will return to Oxford next week.
